questions.text: In ocular surface examination, and dry eye staining, which of the following orders of dyes is used:

options.label: A
options.text: Fluorescein, then Rose bengal and then Lissamine green

options.label: B
options.text: Rose bengal, then Lissamine green and then Fluorescein

options.label: C
options.text: Lissamine green, then Rose bengal and fluorescein.

options.label: D
options.text: Rose bengal, then fluorescein and lissamine green

questions.correct_answer: A. Fluorescein, then Rose bengal and then Lissamine green
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fluorescein, then Rose bengal and then Lissamine green Fluorescein→, Rose bengal → Lissamine green is the better order to pick for use in ocular surface examination and dry eye staining.

Highyeild:

A fluorescein eye stain test is a test administered using a special dye to check the outside of your eye for injuries or irritation . The test is usually ordered if your doctor suspects you have damage on your cornea or foreign objects in your During the test, an eye doctor blots the surface of the eye with a small strip of paper coated in orange fluorescein dye, and then asks the patient to blink quickly. Corneal abrasions or foreign particles will cause abnormal results Indications Diagnosis of dry eye disease Standardized grading of corneal and conjunctival staining. Measurement of TBUT (tear film breakup time) Tear meniscus height Identifying and monitoring corneal epithelial defects, corneal ulcers, corneal abrasions Applanation tonometry Perforating injury - Seidel’s test: If a perforation and active leak exist, the fluorescein is diluted by the aqueous and will appear as a yellow-green stream (of the diluted dye) within the dark orange (concentrated) dye Nasolacrimal duct patency Trauma to canaliculus Fluorescein Fundus Angiography/FFA

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Fluorescein dye for ulcer Rose bengal stain dye the abraded part of corneal ulcer diagnosis Lissamine green dye used in corneal ulcer diagnosis

questions.text: On administration of phenylephrine, the following change was noted as shown in the images below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nodular episcleritis The image shows a nodule surrounded by redness. On administration of phenylephrine blanching of superficial episcleral vessels is seen .Hence the probable diagnosis is nodular episcleritis

Highyeild:

Phenylephrine is a drug that can be used to distinguish between episcleritis and scleritis. In episcleritis, a drop of phenylephrine 2.5% causes visible blanching of the episcleral vessels, but will not do so in scleritis. The redness of episcleritis should improve with instillation of phenylephrine, as the episcleral vessels constrict, but the redness of scleritis should not improve. Clinically two type of presentation may occur: Simple episcleritis is characterized by sectorial or diffuse inflammation of the episclera. Nodular episcleritis is characterized by pink or purple flat nodule surrounded by injection.Usually situated 2-3 mm away from the limbus. The nodule is firm and tender and can be moved separately from the sclera and the overlying conjunctivitis. Type of scleritis Anterior scleritis: the most common type, affecting the front of the It can be non-necrotising (diffuse or nodular) or necrotising (with or without inflammation). Posterior scleritis: a rare type, affecting the back of the It can cause complications such as retinal detachment or optic nerve compression. Exogenous scleritis: caused by external factors such as trauma, surgery, or Endogenous scleritis: caused by systemic diseases such as syphilis or tuberculosis.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option A. Nodular scleritis: Scleritis is a more severe inflammation involving the deeper layers of the sclera. Nodular scleritis presents as nodules on the sclera. Similar to nodular episcleritis, blanching of vascularity after phenylephrine use would be inconsistent with the expected response in nodular scleritis. Option C.Nodular phlyctenular conjunctivitis also called; Phlyctenular keratoconjunctivitis is a nodular inflammation of the cornea or conjunctiva that results from a hypersensitivity reaction to a foreign antigen . Blanching of vascularity after phenylephrine use is not typically associated with nodular phlycten . Option D. Conjunctivitis, also known as pink eye, is inflammation of the outermost layer of the white part of the eye and the inner surface of the Blanching of vascularity after phenylephrine use is not specific to conjunctivitis and may not be a significant diagnostic feature.

questions.text: Which of the following are direct gonioscopes? Goldman Richardson Koeppe Zeiss Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

B,C Koeppe lenses are specifically designed for direct gonioscopy. They are small, handheld lenses with a concave shape and a mirrored surface. They are placed directly on the eye’s surface to visualize the anterior chamber angle.

Highyeild:

Gonioscope is used for the measurement of the angle of the anterior chamber . The types of gonioscopy includes: Direct gonioscopy Allows for direct visualization of the chamber Examples of direct gonio lenses include Koeppe, Barkan, Wurst, Swan-Jacob, or Richardson lenses . During direct gonioscopy, the viewer has an erect view of the angle Direct gonioscopy is most easily performed with the patient supine and in the operating room for an exam under anesthesia or a MIGS procedure. Indirect gonioscopy Examples of indirect gonioscopy lenses include the Posner, Sussman, Zeiss, and Goldmann lenses . These are more commonly used in the clinic setting. The viewer in indirect gonioscopy will have an inverted and slightly foreshortened image of the opposite angle because the light from the angle is reflected off a mirror and

:

Explanation for other options: - Goldmann lenses are commonly used in various ophthalmic examinations and procedures,but they are not commonly used in direct gonioscopy. They are used in assessing the anterior chamber angle during indirect Richardson: They are not commonly used in indirect Koeppe: Specifically designed for direct They are small handheld lenses with concave shape and a mirrored surface. Zeiss is a well-known manufacturer of ophthalmic equipment and instruments,including lenses. Zeiss may produce a variety of lenses for different purposes in ophthalmology.

questions.text: What is the earliest change in glaucoma on perimetry?

options.label: A
options.text: Isopter contraction and baring of blind spot

questions.correct_answer: A. Isopter contraction and baring of blind spot
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Isopter contraction and baring of blind spot Glaucoma change on perimeter is typically an isopter contraction and baring of the blind spot.

Highyeild:

Glaucoma typically involves elevated intraocular pressure (pressure inside the eye), which can lead to damage to the optic nerve fibers over time. This damage often results in gradual and irreversible vision loss, starting with peripheral (side) vision and potentially progressing to central vision if not managed properly. The optic nerve changes in glaucoma primarily involve Isopter contraction refers to mild generalized constriction of both peripheral and central Although it is the earliest but little diagnostic significance occurring in glaucoma. Optic Nerve Head Cupping: One of the most characteristic changes in glaucoma is the cupping of the optic nerve head . This refers to the enlargement and excavation of the central part of the optic nerve head (the point where the nerve fibers leave the eye and enter the brain). As the nerve fibers are damaged and die, this area becomes hollowed out , resembling a “cup .” This cupping can be measured and quantified to monitor the progression of the disease. Nerve Fiber Layer Thinning : The loss of nerve fibers due to glaucoma results in a thinning of the nerve fiber layer that surrounds the optic nerve This can often be observed through imaging techniques like optical coherence tomography (OCT), which can visualize and measure the thickness of the retinal nerve fiber layer. Visual Field Defects : As the optic nerve damage progresses, visual field defects These are areas of the visual field where vision is impaired or lost. In glaucoma, these defects typically start at the periphery and can progress to involve more central areas of vision if the disease is not effectively managed. Optic Nerve Blood Flow Changes : Glaucoma can affect the blood flow to the optic nerve, potentially contributing to its damage. Reduced blood flow can further compromise the health of the nerve fibers

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option A: Static perimetry Used in quantification and tracking of visual changes in established glaucoma. constant and moved centrally with detection. Option B: In kinetic perimetry (not static perimetry) stimulus intensity is held,it is used to map a patient’s hill of vision in order to identify regions of normal and abnormal sensitivity to light Option C: Optic disc changes are much greater than visual field changes. Therefore visual field defects need not correspond to optic nerve head abnormalities to be classified as glaucoma.
